value2: non-imperative verb form + special prohibitive marker
comment: problem: imperative has person markers -an/-an-aj but usually does not use them - bare stem functions as imperative 2sg (+ -aj = 2pl). For the prohibitive, -an (2sg) is obligatory, so the questions are whether a) ma-…-an(-aj) is a circumfix, and b) whether prohibitve marker ma- is attached to the bare stem or to the imperative --> maybe it is the easiest and most straightforward way to classify stem-an-aj as imperative to which ma- is attached (spares the troubles of classifiying both person markers)

regular imperative + regular negation marker
comment: particle baχ can also be used (to make the prohibition stronger)
example_comment: The grammar states that ha is used to mark warnings and prohibitions. However, the sentence is also correct without the particle, which can also be used as an emphatic particle in positive imperatives. I.e. -ma- is the actual negation marker, corresponding to the normal negation also used in indicative declaratives

value2: non-imperative verb form + special prohibitive marker
comment: Prefix ma- is inserted between preverb and stem in complex verbs (interfix -t'- is then added)
example_comment: person markers: -t/-t:a (2sg), -t:a-ja (2pl); thematic markers: -u (intransitive), -i (transitive)

value2: non-imperative verb form + special prohibitive marker
comment: Prefix ma- is inserted between preverb and stem in complex verbs; only imperfective stem if verb has both; suffixes …-Vt(:a), -Vt:a-ja to mark singular and plural
example_comment: suffixes: Sg. -ut(:a), -it(:a), -at(:a); Pl. -ut:aj(a), -it:aj(a), -at:aj(a) -> depending on thematic marker (-u = intransitive; -i= transitive), so actually condensed version could be: -t/-t:a (2sg), -t:aj(a)

value2: non-imperative verb form + special prohibitive marker
comment: Prohibitive not based on imperative: (1) insensibility to (in)transitivity; (2) vowel -a in marker
example_comment: thematic vowel of Initial Stem (č'inni) is syncoped

value2: non-imperative verb form + special prohibitive marker
translation as in source: Girl, don't go on the road!
translation: Girl, don't go on the road!
example_comment: -o ending seems to stem from imperative of transitive verbs, so probably the prohibitive ending is a combination of a negation marker -aq and the imperative marker -o

value2: non-imperative verb form + special prohibitive marker
comment: marker inserted between preverb and imperfective root; differing suffixation for transitives (-u/v; plural marker for HPL) and intransitives (agreement marker)
translation as in source: Ne lave pas la robe qui n'est pas tachée de boue!
translation: Don't wash the dress which is not mud-stained!
example_comment: transitive markers: -u/v (2sg), -(v)ay (2pl); intransitive markers: -a (masculine), -u (feminine)

value2: regular imperative + regular negation marker
comment: no specialized proh. marker, seems to be used for negation in general (abdullaevaetal2014: 86)
example_comment: Plural marking: -гыз/-гиз after negation marker

comment: marker ma- can also be used as an infix; for the prohibitive of durative verbs, the durative stem is used

comment: plain verb root seems to function as the imperative, so the type of stem can probably be analysed as an imperative

comment: If the verb has a preverb, marker -mV- comes in between those elements. Otherwise it is the first element before the stem.

value2: non-imperative verb form + special prohibitive marker
comment: prohibitive marker after spatial prefix, but before expressive prefix

value2: non-imperative verb form + special prohibitive marker
comment: 2sg suffix -an; 2pl -an-aj (?) -> -an seems to be a specialized prohibitive suffix (2sg), while -aj is a general 2pl morpheme also used for the positive imperative, i.e. analysis as -PROH2sg-pl (?); therefore mV-…-an = circumfix?
